summary: severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) infections in humans are generally mild and self-limited. there was limited research on the tissue tropism and host response following human infection with coronaviruses. a novel coronavirus was detected in two patients from Saudi Arabia and Qatar (10, 11) retrospective investigation of an outbreak of severe respiratory illness in Zarqa, Jordan, in April 2012 (14) confirmed that at least some of these cases were also caused by human betacoronavirus lineage C virus EMC (HCoV-EMC) some have given a history of contact with animals (e.g., camels and sheep) (13), and a zoonotic origin of the infection is considered likely. we have previously used ex vivo cultures of human bronchial and lung tissue to study the tissue tropism, virus replication kinetics, apoptosis, and immune responses of HCoV-EMC infection. we now use ex vivo cultures of human bronchial and lung tissue to study the tissue tropism, virus replication kinetics, apoptosis, and innate immune responses of HCoV-EMC infection. all the experiments were performed in a biosafety level 3 biocontainment facility at the university of Hong Kong. 96-well tissue culture plates of the respective cells were used for the virus titration assay for HCoV-EMC and HCoV-229E (MRC-5 cells) the cells were washed once with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and the cells were replenished with MEM with 2% FBS and 1% mal tissues were infected with HCoV-229E, HCoV-EMC, and SARS-CoV. the cells were infected with HCoV-229E, HCoV-EMC, and HPAI H5N1 virus at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) after 1 h of virus adsorption at 37°C, the virus inoculum was removed.
